patients.name: Jane Doe
patients.cmiExplanation: High case-mix intensity driven by poorly controlled diabetes, hypertension, and metabolic risk factors.
patients.hccRiskExplanation: Multiple metabolic HCC categories (diabetes with complications, hypertensive heart disease) raise expected utilization.
clinicalSummary: Very high clinical risk driven by poorly controlled diabetes (A1c 9.1%) and hypertension.
3 ED visits and 1 inpatient stay in the past 12 months, several potentially avoidable.
Medication adherence below 70% for metformin and ACE inhibitor.
careGaps: Overdue for diabetic retinal exam (> 18 months).
No documented annual wellness visit this year.
No LDL panel in the last 12 months.
utilizationSummary: 3 ED visits in the past 12 months (2 flagged as ambulatory care–sensitive).
1 inpatient admission for chest pain observation.
sdohSummary: Moderate food insecurity; reports difficulty affording healthy meals.
Intermittent transportation barriers to in-person visits.
Living in a high-rent area with limited affordable housing options.

communityResources.name: Second Harvest Heartland
communityResources.description: Food assistance and pantry locator for Minnesota residents.

communityResources.name: United Way 211 Housing Resources
communityResources.description: Housing stability counseling and emergency rental assistance information.

communityResources.name: Metro Transit Discount Programs
communityResources.description: Reduced-fare transit options for low-income riders.

activePrograms: Enrolled in virtual diabetes coaching (low engagement).
Eligible for pharmacy consultation and social work outreach.
nextBestActions: Outbound call from care manager within 7 days to re-engage in diabetes coaching.
Schedule telehealth PCP follow-up within 14 days; coordinate labs and retinal exam referral.
Connect to community food support and transportation resources.
actionableRecommendations: Tighten glycemic control with medication titration and frequent follow-up.
Enroll in a structured nutrition program with grocery cost supports.
Establish transportation assistance (rideshare vouchers or community van) for in-person visits.

patients.name: John Smith
patients.cmiExplanation: Moderate case-mix driven by COPD with intermittent exacerbations.
patients.hccRiskExplanation: Chronic lung disease risk with smoking history drives above-average expected cost.
clinicalSummary: Moderate clinical risk driven by COPD with intermittent exacerbations.
Smoking cessation counseling documented, still actively smoking.
careGaps: No pulmonology follow-up in the last 18 months.
utilizationSummary: 2 ED visits in the past 24 months for shortness of breath.
No inpatient admissions in the past 12 months.
sdohSummary: Lives alone with limited social support.
Occasional difficulty arranging transportation to specialty appointments.

communityResources.name: Transit Assistance Program (TAP) – Metro Transit
communityResources.description: Discounted transit fares for eligible low-income riders.

activePrograms: Enrolled in digital COPD education program.
Eligible for smoking cessation program with incentives.
nextBestActions: Proactive outreach to enroll in smoking cessation program with rewards.
Schedule pulmonology consult and spirometry within 3 months.
Set standing orders for annual flu and pneumonia vaccines.
actionableRecommendations: Enroll in an intensive smoking cessation pathway with pharmacotherapy support.
Consider home-based spirometry or remote monitoring for symptom trends.
Coordinate transportation support for pulmonology and smoking cessation visits.

patients.name: Member_1006
primaryConditions: Acute kidney injury / end-stage renal disease
secondaryConditions: History of prosthetic aortic valve (post replacement)
History of sepsis / recurrent severe infections
patients.cmiExplanation: High case-mix intensity driven by severe liver disease (cirrhosis/hepatic failure), renal failure/ESRD and multiple ICU-level inpatient episodes (sepsis).
patients.hccRiskExplanation: Multiple high-weight HCC categories for decompensated cirrhosis, ESRD and cardiac comorbidities drive substantially elevated resource needs.
patients.copdRiskExplanation: No clear COPD diagnosis codes in claims; low estimated COPD risk.
patients.edUseExplanation: Multiple ED-level evaluation/critical care claims in April–June 2025 and repeated urgent evaluations indicate very high near-term ED utilization risk.
patients.inpatientExplanation: Recent sustained inpatient stays including many ICU-level claims in May–June 2025 suggest a very high probability of further inpatient use in near term, particularly for complications of cirrhosis and renal issues.
patients.heartDiseaseExplanation: Prosthetic aortic valve (2024 replacement) plus atrial fibrillation and hypertensive heart disease indicate substantial ongoing cardiovascular care needs and risk of heart-related complications.
clinicalSummary: 55-year-old with prosthetic aortic valve and history of aortic valve replacement (2024). In 2025 the member experienced a massive inpatient episode cluster for sepsis and hepatic failure related to alcoholic cirrhosis, with variceal bleeding, melena and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
High recent inpatient and ED utilization with substantial one-time and ongoing multi-organ failure risks (liver failure, renal failure/ESRD, coagulopathy).
careGaps: Need for tightly coordinated hepatology, nephrology and cardiology follow-up across care settings.
Alcohol use disorder treatment and relapse-prevention plan not clearly documented.
Requires structured transitional care and explicit goals-of-care planning.
utilizationSummary: High recent inpatient and ED utilization including prolonged ICU stays in May–June 2025.
Multiple critical-care and high-acuity encounters related to cirrhosis, sepsis and renal failure.
keyTrends: Large spike in 2025 spending driven by a concentrated cluster of high-cost inpatient claims for sepsis and hepatic failure (May–June 2025).
Ongoing complexity: multi-organ involvement (liver failure, renal failure/ESRD, coagulopathy, GI bleeding, atrial fibrillation) driving repeated high-acuity care.
High acute care intensity (ED + ICU + multiple high-cost procedural claims) with associated readmission and near-term mortality risk.
statisticalInsights: 2025 total spend (~$496,647) is ~8.6x the 2024 spend (~$57,808); the majority of 2025 costs are attributable to inpatient sepsis/hepatic failure episodes in May–June 2025.
Top single inpatient claim observed exceeds $200,000 for sepsis-related ICU care, within a cluster of multi-day high-intensity stays.
Multiple high-dollar claims in the same hospitalization period (several >$10k, several >$30k) are consistent with prolonged ICU stay and complex procedures.
costDrivers: Major inpatient sepsis episodes and associated ICU care, including a large line-item sepsis-related claim in May 2025.
Complications of alcoholic cirrhosis: hepatic failure, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, portal hypertension, variceal bleeding and repeated paracenteses.
Acute kidney injury / ESRD-related inpatient care and critical care billing, including repeated dialysis and renal support codes.
Procedures and imaging during the hospitalization cluster (CT abdomen/pelvis, endoscopy/bleeding control, multiple critical care and procedural codes).
Baseline costs for valve replacement and cardiac follow-up in 2024.

communityResources.name: Minnesota Assistance Council for Veterans (MACV) – Financial & Housing Support
communityResources.description: Helps eligible Minnesotans with housing stability and financial counseling.

communityResources.name: United Way 211 – Financial & Social Services
communityResources.description: Telephone and web-based navigation to local financial, food, and housing supports.

communityResources.name: Nonemergency Medical Transportation (NEMT) – Minnesota DHS
communityResources.description: Transportation benefit for patients needing rides to covered medical services.

actionableRecommendations: Immediate assignment to complex care / case management to coordinate hepatology, nephrology, cardiology, and primary care follow-up.
Enroll in a liver-disease disease management program (hepatology clinic, variceal surveillance, ascites management, SBP prophylaxis plans).
Assess and implement alcohol use disorder treatment and relapse-prevention (medication-assisted therapy plus counseling) given alcoholic cirrhosis diagnosis codes.
Renal follow-up: evaluate need for ongoing dialysis, outpatient nephrology care, and vascular access planning if ESRD persists.
Medication review and bleeding risk management (thrombocytopenia, varices, anticoagulation for A-fib) to reduce GI bleeding readmissions.
Transitional care interventions post-discharge (follow-up within 7 days, home health if appropriate) to reduce readmission risk.
Palliative care / goals-of-care discussion early given advanced liver disease and recurrent critical illness; consider hospice evaluation when appropriate.

realWorldEvidence.title: Hospital readmissions and outcomes in patients with decompensated cirrhosis
Impact of alcohol use disorder treatment on outcomes in alcohol-related liver disease
Integrated care pathways for cirrhosis: reducing unplanned admissions and mortality
Predictors of ICU utilization and cost in end-stage liver disease
